results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 16]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

A short film of a road trip to Albany, Western Australia, including a visit to the whale processing station, in operation at the time of the film. The Cheynes Beach Whaling Station, located at Frenchman Bay in King George Sound, east of Albany, operated from 1952 to 1978 and was the last operating whaling station in Australia.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 kangaroo in open bushland with gumtrees in the background, filmed at dusk or dawn
00:00:18:00 men working on the whale processing station, cutting large pieces of a whale carcass and hosing down the deck
00:01:06:00 a signpost pointing to ‘Albany (21)’ in one direction and ‘Whaling Station (1)’ in the other, with the coastline in the background
00:01:15:00 view from inside the front windscreen of a vehicle driving along the road, leaving Western Australia; a sign gradually appears reading ‘State Border, Come Again to Western Australia’
00:01:36:00 what appears to be a 1950s model Bedford camper van driving down the road through swirls of dust

results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 14]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This film contains snippets of scenes from travels around Victoria. Firstly the Hume Dam (formerly Hume Weir) which is a major dam across the Murray River in New South Wales. Constructed between 1919 and 1936 and involving hydro-power as well as flood mitigation and irrigation, the Hume Dam would have been a major attraction at the time, the 1940s. There are also some scenes of the family children during what seems to be a stop along the way.

This very short black and white film is faded throughout.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:24:00 a man in suit and hat clambering over large boulders and looking out at a view
00:00:45:00 the spillway drains at the Hume Dam
00:01:05:00 children smiling at the camera while standing near a car
00:01:17:00 one of the children holds what might be a small rabbit or possum

results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This film shows the Malins family in a montage of holidays and events in Victoria spanning several years from 1946 to the 1950s (not in precise chronological order). Highlights include a visit to Melbourne Zoo, trips to the beach along the Great Ocean Road and to Phillip Island, as well as trips to the snow at Lake Mountain. Malins frequently captured road signs of their travel destinations, including Anglesea, Lorne, Wye River and Cowes. Other moments captured include children’s birthday parties, horse riding and children at school (possibly Koonung Heights Primary School in Mont Albert North, 1954–1993).

The film also features footage of an historic gathering at the Shrine of Remembrance on the occasion of Field Marshal Bernard Law Montgomery’s visit to Melbourne in 1947.

Selected highlights (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:02:00 (upside down footage) caged orangutan at Zoo eating an ice cream
00:00:15:00 entrance to Melbourne Zoo
00:00:20:00 visitor hands food to a white-cheeked gibbon through cage fence
00:00:29:00 George, Sybil, Helen and John picnic on lawn, with the Taggart family
00:00:45:00 children ride the open-carriage train, ‘Zoo Spirit of Progress’ written on side of driver’s car (a reference to Victorian Railways premier express train from Melbourne to Albury)
00:01:07:00 children riding on an Indian Elephant
00:01:15:00 horse performing tricks for audience, balancing on a see-saw, riding and bucking in the arena with a baboon (possibly a hamadryas baboon) on back
00:01:40:00 George, Sybil, Helen and John with Mabel Malins (Nana) having a picnic with fire next to river, great shots of family members eating and smiling, at Healesville Sanctuary
00:02:40:00 Children play in yard. One boy wearing an ‘indian’ costume rides a tricycle; another boy rides a rocking horse; two girls push prams with dolls. Christmas morning at Rathmines Road, Hawthorn.
00:03:20:00 children and mother in caravan trailer, portable radio, bicycle and a 1940s Chevrolet Utility vehicle (Ute)
00:03:48:00 road sign ‘Anglesea – please slow down’
00:04:09:00 ‘Great Ocean Road’ Memorial Arch
00:04:25:00 road sign ‘Lorne – please slow down’
00:04:28:00 children walking in water and climbing on rocks at the beach
00:05:02:00 Sybil and girl standing next to road sign ‘Wye River’ at bridge
00:05:11:00 boy playing with toy boat in water
00:05:17:00 group of children paddling a yellow inflatable dinghy
00:05:51:00 John holding a small fish that he caught
00:05:59:00 gathering of families, playing games on beach
00:06:29:00 two children in bath, Helen and John
00:07:00:00 family, including Mabel Malins, celebrating Helen’s sixth birthday with cake at dining table
00:07:25:00 family in snow with sled, having a snowball fight at Lake Mountain
00:08:35:00 Helen and John at horse-riding school on country road. A man and a boy pass by standing on the back of a flatbed ute.
00:08:58:00 children ride in a horse drawn cart with a crop harvest (possibly corn)
00:09:07:00 group of nurses surround new born baby, Ruth, as she leaves hospital. Ethel Taggart briefly pictured.
00:09:17:00 people riding horses across country road
00:09:35:00 baby (Ruth) amused by family members at Whitehorse Road, Balwyn
00:10:36:00 baby hops and slides along the floor
00:10:55:00 family exiting St Mark’s Church Camberwell in formal clothing, after Ruth’s chistening; priest holding baby
00:11:41:00 John and Helen walking Ruth (toddler) in harness at Doncaster Road; John wearing leg braces
00:12:11:00 children riding on carousel at San Remo
00:12:39:00 John pushing Ruth in swing; John wearing leg calipers
00:12:56:00 John presented with the dux award at a school, Balwyn Primary School
00:13:13:00 family playing tennis-like game at Wye River beach; Mabs, Ruth and Janet playing with sand
00:13:45:00 in a lounge room, next to a fireplace, George and Sybil and their two daughters throw beach balls to each other (217 Doncaster Road with Bill Gladstone, Ruth and Janet)
00:14:20:00 intertitle card “Wake’y Wake’y”: a day in the life of Ruth and Janet
00:15:33:00 Ruth and Janet holding toys, a baby doll and a plush dog
00:15:45:00 intertitle card “Breakfast”
00:16:10:00 intertitle card “Off to School”: Sybil waving goodbye to her daughters who leave the home with their ports (small briefcases)
00:16:26:00 the girls running through a playground
00:16:39:00 intertitle card “Assembly”: outdoor gathering of students standing in line formations, hand on heart
00:17:16:00 students march into classrooms; crates of glass milk bottles stacked outside one classroom
00:17:46:00 Australian flag blowing in the wind
00:17:54:00 intertitle cards “Forestry Commission’s Lecture”; “Arbor Day at Koonung School 1956”
00:18:10:00 intertitle card “Mr. Godfrey – Our Headmaster”
00:18:26:00 intertitle card “Frances, Joanne and Janet Planting a Tree”
00:18:51:00 adults and children watch as children plant trees (excellent example of 1950s fashion)
00:19:00:00 classroom puppet show, children performing a song and dance for parents
00:20:10:00 girl writing in book at a wooden desk; the desks have ink bottle holders
00:20:30:00 group of children dancing in formation outside
00:21:50:00 Janet’s 6th birthday party: hildren wearing homemade party hats with blowers, sit around a cake and snack spread
00:22:17:00 Nan, Ruth and Janet at the Nobbies Phillip Island, then riding wooden belly boards at Wye River with Dora Kennedy and son John
00:22:58:00 girl and dog climbing on rocks at beach
00:23:03:00 young man fishing from rocks at beach
00:23:11:00 family takes shelter under rocks
00:23:23:00 family riding inflatable dinghy in the Yarra River, Warrandyte
00:24:11:00 koala sitting in and climbing a tree
00:24:23:00 road sign ‘Cowes – please slow down’
00:24:28:00 crossing the wooden bridge to Phillip Island
00:25:21:00 men playing golf in Apollo Bay next to beach, with boats and distant landscape in background
00:25:30:00 putting on golf green
00:25:58:00 “C.O.R.” written on a weathervane
00:26:02:00 Pontiac driving on Great Ocean Road, with wide shot of hillside coastline
00:26:51:00 car bogged on a snow covered road, people attempt to release it
00:27:02:00 children having a snowball fight
00:27:13:00 people make a snowman, dressed with a hat, scarf and buttons
00:27:38:00 riding sleds down a snow covered hill
00:28:32:00 wide shot of tree covered mountains and valleys
00:29:06:00 large group of children and adults riding horses in country location
00:29:59:00 large gathering of people at Shrine of Remembrance; soldier marches across the front of shrine
00:30:22:00 soldiers wearing slouch hats marching toward the shrine; the reflecting pool (removed in the early 1950s) is partially shown with Melbourne skyline in distance
00:30:37:00 Highly decorated men in uniform gather. Man wearing black beret is Field Marshal Bernard Law Montgomery, 1st Viscount Montgomery of Alamein. His presence places this footage in 1947. Surrounded by enormous crowd of people, including police officers wearing a black bobby helmet.
00:31:10:00 family in Chevrolet Ute with caravan trailer
00:31:28:00 family at beach dressed in skirts made of newspaper, bows and flowers in hair; men wearing stuffed brassieres perform a dance
00:32:05:00 people catching waves, riding wooden belly boards
00:32:34:00 Australian National Airways plane (possibly a Douglas DC-4), ‘Bungana’ written on exterior of cockpit. Propellers start to spin, plane moves.
00:33:03:00 Ansett Airways plane (possibly a Douglas DC-3), turns on tarmac
00:33:06:00 man on horse in residential area, Bulleen Riding School
00:33:10:00 fancy dress party at 217 Doncaster Road; children in costumes (yellow bird and nurse) in yard at “Heath’s home”
00:33:22:00 large gathering of children and women at Wattle Park with picnic baskets (Janet’s kindergarten)

description_for_label:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This film shows the Malins family in a montage of holidays and events in Victoria spanning several years from 1946 to the 1950s (not in precise chronological order). Highlights include a visit to Melbourne Zoo, trips to the beach along the Great Ocean Road and to Phillip Island, as well as trips to the snow at Lake Mountain. Malins frequently captured road signs of their travel destinations, including Anglesea, Lorne, Wye River and Cowes. Other moments captured include children’s birthday parties, horse riding and children at school (possibly Koonung Heights Primary School in Mont Albert North, 1954–1993).

The film also features footage of an historic gathering at the Shrine of Remembrance on the occasion of Field Marshal Bernard Law Montgomery’s visit to Melbourne in 1947.

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 4 and Reel 5] [excerpts]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

The collection is filmed on 16mm and 9.5mm film and the films can sometimes be a bit damaged and shaky.

This 9.5mm example is from excerpts of Reels 4 and 5, showing scenes of Jack’s family and friends enjoying their scrambler motor bikes in muddy conditions at Korweinguboora, near Ballarat, Victoria. A group of friends are then shown travelling around the Victorian countryside on motorcycles (motorbikes). Motorcycles have been filmed from a vehicle travelling alongside. The bike riders gather for the camera at the ‘Atlantic Garage’ possibly in Ballarat and then head off for a ride down a dusty country road.

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film contains great footage of a trip to Japan, including urban scenes, Japanese cars, visits to temples and socialising with Japanese locals.

This film was made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:14:00 view from the plane as it takes off, including the Sydney Opera House and the Sydney Harbour Bridge
00:01:32:00 coastline from the plane

00:14:00:00 cable car on a busy city street

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 31]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 88m film.

This film showcases Wilson’s Promontory in Victoria, in particular the coastlines and islands as the filming is done from on board a motorsail boat. Wallace captures the dramatic rocky formations of the shores of the Promontory as well as fishing off the boat and preparing the catch. The fish is likely to be local favourite, ‘King George Whiting’.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:08:00 a woman takes photographs from the deck of a moving ‘motorsail’ boat
00:00:45:00 a mountainous island comes into view followed by views of rocky shorelines and cliffs
00:03:03:00 a boat crosses the water
00:03:18:00 fishing off the back of the moving boat
00:05:35:00 seagulls sitting on the wavy water surface
00:05:51:00 spectacular rocks on the shoreline
00:06:17:00 fish catch in a crate and struggling to remove the fish hook
00:07:10:00 views from the boat looking toward the rocky shoreline
00:08:40:00 lighthouse at South East Point built in 1859
00:10:55:00 waterbirds standing on shoreline rocks
00:11:18:00 gutting and filleting fish on old wooden crates in the stern of the boat
00:11:26:00 a speed boat passes by
00:12:11:00 pier and fishing

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 166]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This is a particularly lovely colour film comprising scenes from Ron and Jess Gadsden’s early life when their children were small, in 1952. They are enjoying life at home (Lansell Rd, Toorak in Melbourne), sitting in the sun with the children, on the beach at Frankston on the Mornington Peninsula and a birthday for one of the girls back at Lansell Rd.

The second half of the film shows school sports at the Geelong Grammar Toorak Campus, ‘Glamorgan’, which Ron films through a round frame.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:59:00 Jess Gadsden teaches one of her children to swim in shallows at Frankston beach
00:01:59:00 view of Frankston bay with cliff top houses in the background
00:02:20:00 filmmaker Ron playing in water with his children
00:03:12:00 Jess preparing lunch on a small plate sitting on the beach
00:04:14:00 birthday party at Jess and Ron Gadsden’s home, with family and pony rides
00:06:42:00 sports day for primary school children with onlooking parents and teachers guiding the proceedings

results.title: Sony Handycam DCR-SX65
results.brief_description: The Sony Handycam DCR-SX65 debuted in 1985 and while other models from the era have been discontinued, it’s been made in various formats ever since. Home videos might have been their original purpose, but camcorders like this have captured footage that has social and political ramifications.

constellations_primary.name: A handheld aesthetic
constellations_primary.description: Looking at the use of handycams and other consumer level devices in moving image works.

results.description: The Sony Handycam DCR-SX65 is what it says: it’s a handy camera. Debuting on the market in 1985, its name came from its compact size that allowed it to fit in the user’s hand and capture their everyday lives more easily. While other models from this era have been discontinued, the Sony Handycam DCR-SX65’s popularity has seen it made in various formats ever since. Home videos might have been their original purpose, but their cost and convivence meant camcorders like this have been used to capture amateur footage that has social and political ramifications all around the world.
